questions.question: A European patent was granted to a German company on 4  January 2023. No opposition was filed. Mr Li and Ms Smith were designated as inventors. On 12 October 2023,  the patent proprietor not ices that Ms Smith was erroneously designated as inventor and that Mr Li is the sole inventor.  Which of the following statements is correct?
options: A. Ms Smith will be deleted as inventor if the patent proprietor requests this in writing .
B. Ms Smith can no longer  be deleted as inventor because no proceedings are pending before the EPO .
C. The patent proprietor can request that  Ms Smith be deleted as inventor but needs Mr Li 's consent  for this .
D. Ms Smith can only be deleted as inventor with her consent .

questions.question: On 10 October 2021, European patent attorney X filed European patent application EP -A with the EPO on the applicant's behalf. Application EP -A was published on 12 April 2023, together  with the extended European search report. On 6  October 2023, the applicant contacts a new European patent attorney  Y to replace X as representative and issues Y with its instructions to reply to the extended European search report. The applicant did not inform X that he would be replaced.  What are the steps necessary to validly appoint representative Y and to avoid any loss of rights for European patent application EP -A?
options: A. New representative Y requests a change of representative, files a response to the extended European search report with the EPO by 12 October 2023 at the latest and files in good time an authorisation signed by the applicant .
B. New representative Y requests a change of representative and files a response to the extended European search report with  the EPO by 12 October 2023 at the latest .
C. New representative Y requests a change of representative and files a response to the extended European search report with the EPO by 23 October 2023 at the latest.

D. New representative Y requests a change of representative, files a response to the extended European search report with the EPO by 23 October 2023 at the latest and files in good time an authorisation signed by the applicant .

questions.question: EP-1 is a regular European patent application (Euro -direct application) .  Which one of the following missed time limits can be remedied for EP -1 before the EPO by requesting re- establishment of rights ?
options: A. T ime limit for pay ing the designation fee
B. T ime limit for requesting examination
C. T ime limit for filing the application within the priority period
D. T ime limit for paying the fee for re- establishment of rights

questions.question: Last week Greta validly filed the international patent application PCT -G with the German Patent and Trade mark Office ( DPMA ) and appointed Hassan to represent her. Hassan is entitled to act before the DPMA  but he is not a European patent attorney. Greta and Hassan are resident in Germany.  Which of the following statements is not correct?
options: A. Hassan can represent Greta before the EPO acting as the International Searching Authority for PCT -G.
B. In order for Hassan to be able to act before the EPO acting as the International Searching Authority , he needs to submit a power of attorney signed by Greta.
C. According to the provisions of the PCT, it is mandatory that the d emand for international preliminary examination is signed by Greta or Hassan.
D. According to the provisions of the PCT, an international application can only be withdrawn by the applicant or an agent appointed by a power of attorney.

questions.question: In which of the following cases is the applicant entitled to a reduction of the filing fee  under Rule  6 EPC ? A declaration of such entitlement has  been made by crossing the relevant box on Form  1001.
options: A. A Spanish European patent attorney files a European patent application in Spanish for a natural person who is resident in Andorra and of Andorra n nationality .

B. A firm whose principal place of business is in Germany and a natural person who is resident in Germany  and of Dutch nationality  jointly file a European patent application in Dutch. The German firm employs 200 people with an annual turnover of EUR 60 million.
C. A natural person resident in the USA and of Belgian nationality files a European patent application in French.
D. A natural person resident in the USA and of Swiss nationality files a European patent application in Italian.

questions.question: Mr Van Holland is a Dutch citizen resident in the Netherlands. He filed a European patent application EP -parent in Dutch, together with  a translation into English. Whil e EP-parent was pending, Mr Van Holland filed a divisional application EP -div in Dutch and requested examination in Dutch. He paid all fees due for EP -div. He has not filed an English translation of EP -div. The Receiving Section has now issued a noting of l oss of rights.  Which of the following statements is correct?
options: A. The deficiency cannot be remedied.
B. Mr Van Holland can remedy the deficiency by filing an English translation of EP -div within two months of notification of the communication  under Rule 112(1) EPC .
C. Mr Van Holland needs to file an English translation of EP -div together with a request for f urther processing.
D. Mr Van Holland needs to file an English translation of EP -div together with a request for re- establishment of rights.

questions.question: During oral proceedings, the opposition division decided to maintain the patent in amended form on the basis of a request in which the description contains a paragraph with handwritten amendments.  Which of the following statements is correct ?
options: A. Upon request the patent proprietor must  pay the fee for publishing a new specification, file translations of the claims and file a formally compliant version of the entire description.

B. If a party files an appeal, the patent proprietor will not be invited to pay the fee for publishing a new specification, file translations of the claims or file a formally compliant version of the amended paragraph  while the appeal proceedings are still pending.

D. If no appeal is filed, the patent proprietor must, upon request, pay the fee for publishing a new specification, file translations of the claims and file a typed version of the amended paragraph within four months.

questions.question: The opposition division revoked European patent EP -B1. The patent proprietor filed an appeal  in time . The b oard of appeal forwarded a copy of the appeal to the o pponent/ respondent with a communication dated 1 June 2023 giving it an opportunity to file comments within a period of four  months.  The opponent/respondent files comments today, 12 October 2023. What further action has to be taken ?
options: A. The opponent/ respondent needs  to request an extension of the period for comment.
B. The opponent/respondent needs to pay a fee for further processing.
C. The opponent/respondent needs to file a substantiated request for reestablishment of rights and pay the associated fee.
D. None of the above.

questions.question: A European patent application was filed on 20 March 2020. Proceedings were interrupted under  Rule 142 EPC on 10  March 2022. The applicant was informed that proceedings would be resumed today, 12 October 2023. No renewal fee has been paid so far . Which of the following statements is correct?
options: A. As no renewal fees have been paid, the application is deemed to be withdrawn .
B. The renewal fees for the third and fourth years can be validly paid without any additional fee on 12 October 2023 at the latest .
C. The renewal fees for the third and fourth years can be validly paid with an additional  fee by 30  April 2024 at the latest .
D. The renewal fees for the third and fourth years can be validly paid without any additional fee by 31  October 2023 at the latest .

**Answer: D**

**Justification:**  
- Explanation of why D is correct. According to Rule 21(1) EPC, an incorrect designation of inventor shall be rectified upon request and only with the consent of the wrongly designated person. Since Ms Smith was erroneously designated as an inventor, she must give her consent for this correction to take place.
- Explanation of why B is incorrect. There is no requirement that proceedings must be pending before the EPO in order to rectify an incorrect designation of inventors. The issue can be addressed even if there are no pending proceedings.
- Explanation of why C is incorrect. Rule 21(1) does not require Mr Li's consent for this rectification; it requires only Ms Smith’s consent as she was the wrongly designated inventor.
- Explanation of why A is incorrect. While the patent proprietor can request that Ms Smith be deleted, such a change cannot occur without Ms Smith’s explicit consent per Rule 21(1) EPC.

**Answer: A**

**Justification:**  
- Explanation of why A is correct. According to EPO regulations and the given context, new representative Y needs to request a change of representative, file a response to the extended European search report with the EPO by 12 October 2023 at the latest (since that’s the deadline for responding), and also ensure that an authorization signed by the applicant is filed in good time. This ensures that there are no issues related to the change of representation, and rights over the application EP -A will be preserved.

- Explanation of why B is incorrect. Option B omits the requirement to file an authorization signed by the applicant, which is crucial for validating the new representative Y’s actions.

- Explanation of why C is incorrect. Option C suggests that the response to the extended European search report should be filed by 23 October 2023 at the latest, but this date is after the actual deadline (12 October 2023) for responding to the extended European search report published on 12 April 2023. Thus, missing this deadline would lead to loss of rights.

- Explanation of why D is incorrect. Option D also suggests filing a response by 23 October 2023 at the latest and includes filing an authorization signed by the applicant. However, like option C, it fails to meet the critical deadline for responding (12 October 2023), which would result in a loss of rights for European patent application EP -A.

**Answer: A**

**Justification:**
- **Explanation of why A is correct:** According to Article 122 and Rule 136 of the Guidelines for Examination in the EPO, re-establishment of rights can be requested if an applicant was unable to observe a time limit despite taking all due care. The time limit for paying the designation fee (option A) falls under these circumstances where the request for re-establishment of rights is possible.

- **Explanation of why B, C, and D are incorrect:**
  - **B:** Time limit for requesting examination cannot be remedied by a request for re-establishment of rights. The rules specifically do not provide for re-establishing rights in this case. Requesting examination under Art. 94(1) in conjunction with Rule 70(1) is considered an independent procedural act and not subject to the re-establishment provisions.
  - **C:** Time limit for filing the application within the priority period (priority claim time limit) cannot be remedied by requesting re-establishment of rights. According to Article 87, if the application was not filed within the required timeframe from the original filing date, the priority is lost and there are no mechanisms provided in the rules for reinstatement.
  - **D:** Time limit for paying the fee for re-establishment of rights itself is a prerequisite for initiating the re-establishment process. If this time limit is missed, it implies that the applicant has not even initiated the request to re-establish their rights, hence this option does not make sense within the context provided.

Thus, only the time limit for paying the designation fee can be remedied through requesting re-establishment of rights as per the applicable EPO regulations.

**Answer: C**

**Justification:**  
- Explanation of why C is incorrect: According to PCT provisions, it is not mandatory that the demand for international preliminary examination be signed by Greta or Hassan. The relevant rules do not specifically mandate who must sign the demand; they simply state that the applicant can appoint a representative and that such a representative may act on their behalf, subject to specific requirements of the authority.

- Explanation of why A is correct: Hassan can represent Greta before the EPO acting as the International Searching Authority for PCT-G if he has been given proper authorization by Greta. The PCT allows representation before search authorities without necessarily requiring a European patent attorney.
  
- Explanation of why B is correct: For Hassan to act on behalf of Greta before the EPO, it would typically be necessary to submit a power of attorney signed by Greta to establish formal authority for Hassan’s actions.

- Explanation of why D is correct: According to PCT provisions, an international application can only be withdrawn by the applicant or an agent appointed by a validly executed power of attorney. This ensures that withdrawal decisions are made with proper authorization and representation.

- Explanation of why C is correct. According to Rule 6 EPC, an individual applicant who is a natural person and resident outside the European Patent Office’s (EPO) contracting states or certain listed countries can be entitled to reduced fees if they are of nationalities of such contracting states. The person in option C is a natural person resident in the USA (a non-contracting state) but holds Belgian nationality (a contracting state). This satisfies the criteria for entitlement under Rule 6 EPC.
  
- Explanation of why B, C, and D are incorrect.

Additionally, filing in Spanish by a patent attorney doesn't necessarily mean entitlement to reduced fees under Rule 6 EPC.
  
  - Option B: This option involves two applicants (a firm and an individual) jointly filing the application, which means they do not qualify for any fee reduction as per Rule 6 EPC. The criteria for reduced fees require that only one natural person who is resident in a non-contracting state can make such a declaration.
  
  - Option D: This option involves an applicant from the USA but of Swiss nationality. While the individual meets the condition of being resident outside a contracting state and holding nationality of one, filing the application in Italian (a language not aligned with their nationality or place of residence) might lead to additional scrutiny that could disqualify them under Rule 6 EPC’s criteria for reduced fees.

Since Mr Van Holland did not file an English translation within two months, he cannot now remedy this deficiency.

- Explanation of why B is incorrect: According to R. 58 and Art. 90(3) EPC, once the noting of loss of rights (under Rule 112(1)) has been issued for a required translation not filed in due time, it cannot be remedied by filing an English translation within two months from notification.

- Explanation of why C is incorrect: Further processing requests under Rule 137 EPC are applicable to deficiencies that can still be remedied; however, the loss of rights noted under Rule 112(1) due to non-compliance with translation requirements cannot be cured by merely filing a translation and requesting further processing.

- Explanation of why D is incorrect: Re-establishment of rights under Article 122 EPC involves demonstrating that the delay was beyond the control of the applicant. Given the specific requirement for timely translations, re-establishing rights would not apply as the failure to meet this procedural requirement cannot be rectified retroactively.

The decision to grant on October 12, 2023, implies that the mention of grant will typically be published about two months later. Thus, for EP-A filed on November 16, 2020, the fourth-year renewal fee would normally be due on November 16, 2023. With a typical grace period of two months from the publication of the European Patent Bulletin (EPB), this implies that payment is valid without additional fees until January 9, 2024.

After grant, these fees should be paid directly to national offices in the chosen validation states. Option B has the correct due date (30 November 2023), but it also incorrectly suggests central payment through the EPO.

- Explanation of why A is correct. According to Rule 159(1) of the European Patent Convention (EPC), for an international application, the applicant must supply a translation if required, specify the documents on which the grant procedure will be based, and pay the filing fee within thirty-one months from the date of filing of the application. Since the search report has been drawn up by the CNIPA and no priority was claimed, the applicant needs to complete Form 1200 (which includes specifying the documents) and pay both the filing fee and the search fee for entry into the EP phase. The renewal fee is not required at this stage because it would be due after thirty-one months from the filing date.

- Explanation of why B is incorrect. Option B incorrectly includes paying the renewal fee for the third year, which is not necessary within 25 months of the filing date. According to Rule 159(1)(g), the third-year renewal fee only needs to be paid if it has fallen due earlier under Rule 51(1).

- Explanation of why C is incorrect. Option C includes appointing a representative, which is not mandatory for entering the EP phase as per Rule 159.

- Explanation of why D is incorrect. None of the above statements correctly identifies the necessary actions if option A (the correct answer) applies.

**Justification:**  
- Explanation of why A is correct. According to Rule 39(2) EPC as mentioned in the case law reference provided (Case Law IV, A.7.2.1), the designation fee must be paid within six months from the date on which the European Patent Bulletin mentions the publication of the European search report. If the applicant withdraws before this deadline and the designation fee has not been paid, the application will be deemed to be withdrawn under Rule 39(2) EPC without incurring a penalty for non-payment, hence allowing a refund.

- Explanation of why B is incorrect. The date of mention of the publication of the European search report is the starting point from which the six-month period begins but not the deadline itself. Hence, withdrawing on or before that date would still require paying the designation fee within the subsequent six months to avoid deemed withdrawal.

- Explanation of why C is incorrect. The designation fee can indeed be refunded if the application is withdrawn before it is paid and before the end of the stipulated time frame (six months from publication mention).

- Explanation of why D is incorrect. The start of substantive examination does not pertain to the deadline for payment or deemed withdrawal related to the designation fee under Rule 39(2) EPC. The relevant time limit pertains to the six-month period post-publication mention in the European Patent Bulletin.

**Answer: B**

**Justification:**  
- Explanation of why B is correct. According to the ADA (Arrangements for Deposit Accounts), specifically Section 13.2, a debit order with a deferred payment date can be revoked in whole or in part until one day before the specified execution date at the latest. Here, the execution date for the debit order is set for 18 October 2024; thus, the latest point in time to revoke part of the order (such as the renewal fee) would be 17 October 2024.

- Explanation of why A, C, and D are incorrect.
    - **A.** 10 October 2024: This date is too early for a partial revocation since the full debit order was just filed that day, and no delay in processing would have occurred by this time. The applicant still has up until one day before the execution date to revoke part of the order.
    - **C.** 18 October 2024: This is incorrect as it is the actual date when the debit order will be executed. According to ADA Section 13.2, a partial revocation can only be made until one day before the execution date (i.e., 17 October 2024).
    - **D.** A debit order cannot be revoked in part: This statement is incorrect as per ADA Section 13.2, which explicitly states that a debit order with a deferred payment can indeed be revoked in whole or in part until the day before execution.

When an applicant fails to meet a deadline and their European patent application is refused as a consequence (such as under Article 90(3) EPC and Rule 60 EPC), the appropriate course of action is to file a notice of appeal within four months from the notification of the refusal decision (see Article 108 EPC). This allows the applicant to challenge the refusal on the grounds that it was improperly issued.

- Explanation of why B, C, and D are incorrect.  
    - Option B suggests filing a request for further processing, which is not applicable in this scenario as there's no provision under the EPC for requesting further processing when an application has already been refused.
    - Option C involves filing a request for re-establishment of rights (Article 122 EPC). However, Article 122(4) explicitly states that re-establishment of rights is ruled out in respect to the time limit for requesting such re-establishment. Therefore, once the deadline has passed and the refusal decision has been issued, a request for re-establishment will not be effective.
    - Option D suggests all options A, B, and C are correct, but since B and C are incorrect as explained above, this option is also incorrect.

**Justification:**  
- Explanation of why D is correct: According to Art. 115 and Rule 114(1) of the EPC, third-party observations can indeed be filed after the publication of a European patent application and must be filed in an official language of the EPO. This ensures that these observations are comprehensible and can be considered by the examining division during their examination process.

- Explanation of why B is incorrect: While it is true that third-party observations must be filed in writing, they may actually be filed anonymously according to Art. 115 of the EPC and Rule 114(1). This means that there is no requirement for them to be non-anonymous.

- Explanation of why C is incorrect: Third-party observations do not require an official fee to be paid; filing these observations is free of charge under the EPO rules. Additionally, while a statement of the grounds on which they are based is useful and often expected, it is not explicitly required for them to be considered by the examining division.

- Explanation of why A is incorrect: The person that files third-party observations will not become a party to the proceedings before the EPO. They do not have any procedural rights in these proceedings, nor is the applicant obliged to respond directly to these observations; rather, it is up to the examining division to consider them and possibly take action accordingly.

Here, the communication was dated 25 September 2024, so the deadline for payment would be 25 November 2024 (not 25 October as stated in option A), but the principle remains correct that additional search fees must be paid within two months.

- Explanation of why B is incorrect: The applicant is required to file a response if they wish to address any issues identified in the provisional opinion accompanying the partial search results. Ignoring this communication could result in adverse consequences, such as examination proceeding without addressing these issues adequately.

- Explanation of why C is incorrect: According to EPC Rule 64(1), if additional fees are paid under protest, a single protest fee should be paid for all the additional search fees being contested, not one per each additional fee. Thus, paying two separate protest fees would not comply with the correct procedure.

- Explanation of why D is incorrect: If no additional search fees are paid within the time limit, only those inventions that were initially searched will continue to be examined. The application as a whole will not be deemed withdrawn; instead, it may proceed for examination in relation to the invention(s) covered by the initial search fee.

- Explanation of why B is correct. According to the Guidelines for Examination in the EPO and recent developments in international patent filing practices, submitting a valid Digital Access Service (DAS) code enables the International Bureau to obtain a certified copy directly from the Luxembourg Intellectual Property Office.
- Explanation of why A is incorrect. Requesting the Luxembourg Intellectual Property Office to prepare and send a certified copy does not align with the current streamlined DAS process used by international offices like the EPO and WIPO (International Bureau).
- Explanation of why C is incorrect. Filing an electronic certified copy directly with the EPO would typically apply for European applications under the EPC framework but not for international patent applications filed via the PCT route through the International Bureau.
- Explanation of why D is incorrect. Although filing a certified copy directly with the International Bureau could theoretically be possible, it is less efficient than using the Digital Access Service (DAS) mechanism to ensure that the priority document is transmitted securely and efficiently between offices.

According to Art. 108 EPC and established case law, only an opponent who participated in opposition proceedings can file an appeal against the decision of the opposition division. In this scenario, if Firm A’s patent was maintained as granted (option B), Firm B, having initially filed an opposition, would have standing to appeal the decision to maintain the patent.
- Explanation of why A is incorrect. If the opposition division decided to revoke the patent, the patent proprietor (Firm A) and not Firm B would be entitled to file an appeal against this decision. Opponents do not appeal revocation decisions but rather seek to uphold such decisions or withdraw their objections if they are satisfied.
- Explanation of why C is incorrect. Third parties who only file observations under Art. 115 EPC (such as Firm C) cannot initiate appeals. They are not considered formal opponents and thus lack standing in the appeal proceedings.
- Explanation of why D is incorrect. If Firm B withdrew its opposition, it would no longer be an opponent within the meaning of the EPC, and therefore would have no right to file an appeal against a decision that maintains the patent as granted. Only active parties with standing are entitled to initiate appeals.
